name: Help.
description: Tries to give you a hint on what to do next.
example:
Lemma example_help :
  0 = 0.
Proof.
Help.
We conclude that (0 = 0).
Qed.

name: We need to show that ((*(alternative) formulation of current goal*)).
description: Generally makes a proof more readable. Has the additional functionality that you can write a slightly different but equivalent formulation of the goal: you can for instance change names of certain variables.
example:
Lemma example_we_need_to_show_that :
  0 = 0.
Proof.
We need to show that (0 = 0).
We conclude that (0 = 0).
Qed.

name: We conclude that ((*current goal*)).
description: Tries to automatically prove the current goal.
example:
Lemma example_we_conclude_that :
  0 = 0.
Proof.
We conclude that (0 = 0).
Qed.

name: Take (*name*) : ((*set*)).
description: Take an arbitrary element from (*set*) and call it (*name*).
example:
Lemma example_take :
  for all x : ℝ,
    x = x.
Proof.
Take x : (ℝ).
We conclude that (x = x).
Qed.

name: Choose (*name_var*) := ((*expression*)).
description: You can use this tactic when you need to show that there exists an x such that a certain property holds. You do this by proposing (*expression*) as a choice for x, giving it the name (*name_var*).
example:
Lemma example_choose : 
  there exists y : ℝ,
    y < 3.
Proof.
Choose y := (2).
We conclude that (& y = 2 < 3).
Qed.

name: Assume that ((*statement*)) ((*optional_label*)).
description: If you need to prove (*statement*) ⇒ B, this allows you to assume that (*statement*) holds, giving it the label (*optional_label*). You can leave out ((*optional_label*)) if you don't wish to name your assumption.
example:
Lemma example_assume :
  ∀ a : ℝ, a < 0 ⇒ - a > 0.
Proof.
Take a : (ℝ).
Assume that (a < 0).
We conclude that (- a > 0).
Qed.

description: Example of a chain of (in)equalities in which every inequality should.
example:
Lemma example_inequalities :
  ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 ⇒ Rmin(ε,1) < 2.
Proof.
Take ε : (ℝ).
Assume that (ε > 0).
We conclude that (& Rmin(ε,1) ≤ 1 < 2).
Qed.

name: Obtain such a (*name_var*).
description: In case a hypothesis that you just proved starts with 'there exists' s.t. some property holds, then you can use this tactic to select such a variable. The variable will be named (*name_var*).
example:
Lemma example_obtain :
  ∀ x : ℝ,
    (∃ y : ℝ, 10 < y ∧ y < x) ⇒
      10 < x.
Proof.
Take x : (ℝ).
Assume that (∃ y : ℝ, 10 < y ∧ y < x) (i).
Obtain such a y.
Qed.

name: Obtain (*name_var*) according to ((*name_hyp*)).
description: In case the hypothesis with name (*name_hyp*) starts with 'there exists' s.t. some property holds, then you can use this tactic to select such a variable. The variable will be named (*name_var*).
example:
Lemma example_obtain :
  ∀ x : ℝ,
    (∃ y : ℝ, 10 < y ∧ y < x) ⇒
      10 < x.
Proof.
Take x : (ℝ).
Assume that (∃ y : ℝ, 10 < y ∧ y < x) (i).
Obtain y according to (i).
Qed.

name: It suffices to show that ((*statement*)).
description: Waterproof tries to verify automatically whether it is indeed enough to show (*statement*) to prove the current goal. If so, (*statement*) becomes the new goal.
example:
Lemma example_it_suffices_to_show_that :
  ∀ ε : ℝ,
    ε > 0 ⇒
      3 + Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 3.
Proof.
Take ε : (ℝ).
Assume that (ε > 0).
It suffices to show that (Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 0).
We conclude that (& Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 2 ≥ 0).
Qed.

name: By ((*lemma or assumption*)) it suffices to show that ((*statement*)).
description: Waterproof tries to verify automatically whether it is indeed enough to show (*statement*) to prove the current goal, using (*lemma or assumption*). If so, (*statement*) becomes the new goal.
example:
Lemma example_it_suffices_to_show_that :
  ∀ ε : ℝ,
    ε > 0 ⇒
      3 + Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 3.
Proof.
Take ε : (ℝ).
Assume that (ε > 0) (i).
By (i) it suffices to show that (Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 0).
We conclude that (& Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 2 ≥ 0).
Qed.

name: It holds that ((*statement*)) ((*optional_label*)).
description: Tries to automatically prove (*statement*). If that works, (*statement*) is added as a hypothesis with name (*optional_label*).
example:
Lemma example_it_holds_that :
  ∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 ⇒
    4 - Rmax(ε,1) ≤ 3.
    
Proof.
Take ε : (ℝ).
Assume that (ε > 0).
It holds that (Rmax(ε,1) ≥ 1) (i).
We conclude that (4 - Rmax(ε,1) ≤ 3).
Qed.

name: By ((*lemma or assumption*)) it holds that ((*statement*)) ((*optional_label*)).
description: Tries to prove (*statement*) using (*lemma*) or (*assumption*). If that works, (*statement*) is added as a hypothesis with name (*optional_label*). You can leave out ((*optional_label*)) if you don't wish to name the statement.
example:
Lemma example_by_it_holds_that :
  ∀ x : ℝ, ∀ y : ℝ,
    (∀ δ : ℝ, δ > 0 ⇒ x < δ) ⇒
      (∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 ⇒ y < ε) ⇒
        x + y < 1.
Proof.
Take x : (ℝ). Take y : (ℝ).
Assume that (∀ δ : ℝ, δ > 0 ⇒ x < δ) (i).
Assume that (∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 ⇒ y < ε) (ii).
By (i) it holds that (x < 1/2).
By ((ii) (1/2)) it holds that (y < 1/2).

We conclude that (x + y < 1).

Qed.

name: We claim that ((*statement*)) ((*optional_label*)).
description: Lets you first show (*statement*) before continuing with the rest of the proof. After you showed (*statement*), it will be available as a hypothesis with name (*optional_name*).
example: We claim that (2 = 2) (two_is_two).

name: We argue by contradiction.
description: Assumes the opposite of what you need to show. Afterwards, you need to make substeps that show that both A and ¬ A (i.e. not A) for some statement A. Finally, you can finish your proof with 'Contradiction.'
example:
Lemma example_contradiction :
  ∀ x : ℝ,
   (∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 ⇒ x < ε) ⇒
     x ≤ 0.
Proof. 
Take x : (ℝ).
Assume that (∀ ε : ℝ, ε > 0 ⇒ x < ε) (i).
We need to show that (x ≤ 0).
We argue by contradiction.
Assume that (¬ (x ≤ 0)).
Define ε1 := (x).
It holds that (ε1 > 0).
By (i) it holds that (x < x).
It holds that (¬ (x < x)).
Contradiction.
Qed.

name: Contradiction
description: If you have shown both A and not A for some statement A, you can write "Contradiction" to finish the proof of the current goal.
example: Contradiction.

name: Because ((*name_combined_hyp*)) both ((*statement_1*)) ((*optional_label_1*)) and ((*statement_2*)) ((*optional_label_2*)).
description: If you currently have a hypothesis with name (*name_combined_hyp*) which is in fact of the form H1 ∧ H2, then this tactic splits it up in two separate hypotheses.
example:
Lemma and_example : for all A B : Prop, A ∧ B ⇒ A.
Take A : Prop. Take B : Prop.
Assume that (A ∧ B) (i). Because (i) both (A) (ii) and (B) (iii).

name: Either ((*case_1*)) or ((*case_2*)).
description: Split in two cases (*case_1*) and (*case_2*).
example:
Lemma example_cases : 
  ∀ x : ℝ, ∀ y : ℝ,
    Rmax(x,y) = x ∨ Rmax(x,y) = y.
Proof. 
Take x : ℝ. Take y : ℝ.
Either (x < y) or (x ≥ y).
- Case (x < y).
  It suffices to show that (Rmax(x,y) = y).
  We conclude that (Rmax(x,y) = y).
- Case (x ≥ y).
  It suffices to show that (Rmax(x,y) = x).
  We conclude that (Rmax(x,y) = x).
Qed.

name: Expand the definition of (*name_kw*) in ((*statement*)).
description: Expands the definition of the keyword (*name_kw*) in the statement (*statement*).
example: Expand the definition of upper bound in (4 is an upper bound for [0, 3)).

name: We show both statements.
description: Splits the goal in two separate goals, if it is of the form A ∧ B
example:
Lemma example_both_statements:
  ∀ x : ℝ, (x^2 ≥ 0) ∧ (| x | ≥ 0).
Proof.
Take x : (ℝ).
We show both statements.
- We conclude that (x^2 ≥ 0).
- We conclude that (| x | ≥ 0).
Qed.

name: We show both directions.
description: Splits a goal of the form A ⇔ B, into the goals (A ⇒ B) and (B ⇒ A)
example:
Lemma example_both_directions:
  ∀ x : ℝ, ∀ y : ℝ,
    x < y ⇔ y > x.
Proof.
Take x : (ℝ). Take y : (ℝ).
We show both directions.
- We need to show that (x < y ⇒ y > x).
  Assume that (x < y).
  We conclude that (y > x).
- We need to show that (y > x ⇒ x < y).
  Assume that (y > x).
  We conclude that (x < y).
Qed.

name: We use induction on (*name*).
description: Prove a statement by induction on the variable with (*name*).
example:
Lemma example_induction :
  ∀ n : ℕ → ℕ, (∀ k : ℕ, n(k) < n(k + 1))%nat ⇒
    ∀ k : ℕ, (k ≤ n(k))%nat.
Proof.
Take n : (ℕ → ℕ).
Assume that (∀ k : ℕ, n(k) < n(k + 1))%nat (i).
We use induction on k.
- We first show the base case, namely (0 ≤ n(0))%nat.
  We conclude that (0 ≤ n(0))%nat.
- We now show the induction step.
  Assume that (k ≤ n(k))%nat.
  By (i) it holds that (n(k) < n(k + 1))%nat.
  We conclude that (& k + 1 ≤ n(k) + 1 ≤ n(k + 1))%nat.
Qed.

name: By ((*lemma or assumption*)) we conclude that ((*statement*)).
description: Tries to directly prove the goal using (*lemma or assumption*) when the goal corresponds to (*statement*).

name: Define (*name*) := ((*expression*)).
description: Temporarily give the name (*name*) to the expression (*expression*)

name: Since ((*extra_statement*)) it holds that ((*statement*)) ((*optional_label*)).
description: Tries to first verify (*extra_statement*) after it uses that to verify (*statement*). The statement gets added as a hypothesis, optionally with the name (*optional_label*).
example: Since (x = y) it holds that (x = z).

name: Since ((*extra_statement*)) we conclude that ((*(alternative) formulation of current goal*)).
description: Tries to automatically prove the current goal, after first trying to prove (*extra_statement*).
example: Since (x = y) we conclude that (x = z).

name: Since ((*extra_statement*)) it suffices to show that ((*statement*)).
description: Waterproof tries to verify automatically whether it is indeed enough to show (*statement*) to prove the current goal, after first trying to prove (*extra_statement*). If so, (*statement*) becomes the new goal.
example:
Lemma example_it_suffices_to_show_that :
  ∀ ε : ℝ,
    ε > 0 ⇒
      3 + Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 3.
Proof.
Take ε : (ℝ).
Assume that (ε > 0).
Since (ε > 0) it suffices to show that (Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 0).
We conclude that (& Rmax(ε,2) ≥ 2 ≥ 0).
Qed.
